verses.text: Then Jonah prayed to the LORD his God from the belly of the fish,
verses.comment: Jonah turns in prayer when he is at his lowest, showing the importance of seeking God even in dire circumstances. The act of prayer from within the fish foreshadows drawing near to God in moments of death or despair.

verses.text: He said: 'I called out to the LORD in my distress, and he answered me; out of the depths of the grave I cried, and you heard my voice.'
verses.comment: Jonah's prayer uses language similar to the Psalms, reflecting a pattern of lament and trust in deliverance. The phrase 'out of the depths of the grave' points to themes of death and resurrection, which will later be fulfilled in Christ's own death and victory over the grave. See also Matthew 12:40.

verses.text: You threw me into the deep, into the heart of the seas, and the flood surrounded me; all your waves and billows passed over me.
verses.comment: Jonah acknowledges God's sovereignty even in judgment. The flood and overwhelming waters often signify trials and purification in Scripture, hinting at spiritual cleansing and the mysterious working of divine providence.

verses.text: Then I said, ‘I am driven away from your sight; yet I will look again toward your holy temple.’
verses.comment: Jonah’s longing to turn to God's holy temple demonstrates the enduring connection between the worshiper and God’s presence. The temple is seen as the center of worship and reconciliation, foreshadowing the greater fulfillment found in Christ's body (John 2:19-21).

verses.text: The waters closed in over me to take my life; the deep surrounded me; seaweed was wrapped around my head.
verses.comment: 'Waters closing in' is an ancient metaphor for death and chaos. Jonah’s imagery closely echoes Psalm 69, linking personal suffering to communal lament and deliverance.

verses.text: I went down to the roots of the mountains; the earth with its bars closed upon me forever; yet you brought up my life from the pit, O LORD my God.
verses.comment: The descent 'to the roots of the mountains' signifies reaching the point of no hope, even touching the realm of the dead. God's deliverance from 'the pit' reveals His power over death—a theme ultimately fulfilled in Christ’s resurrection.

verses.text: When my soul fainted within me, I remembered the LORD, and my prayer came to you, into your holy temple.
verses.comment: Jonah’s memory of God and prayer toward the temple reinforces the importance of persevering faith and the power of intercessory prayer, particularly in crisis.

verses.text: Those who worship worthless idols forsake the mercy that could be theirs.
verses.comment: Jonah contrasts idol worship and the mercy found in faithful worship. This underscores the call to exclusive devotion to the true God—mercy is found in fidelity to God's covenant rather than in other allegiances.

verses.text: But I, with shouts of thanksgiving, will sacrifice to you; what I have vowed I will fulfill. Salvation belongs to the LORD!
verses.comment: Sacrifice, thanksgiving, and fulfilling vows emphasize obedient worship. Notice the importance of sacrificial offering and making vows to God—this hints at the necessity of both genuine faith and concrete acts demonstrating devotion.

verses.text: And the LORD spoke to the fish, and it vomited Jonah out onto dry land.
verses.comment: God’s command over creation is absolute. This miraculous deliverance prefigures resurrection—Jonah’s three days in the fish symbolize Christ’s three days in the tomb and His triumph over death (see Matthew 12:40).
